author: nielstron
title: Imperative Smart Contracts
description: Many programmers are unfamiliar with functional programming languages like Haskell/Plutus. Let's develop an imperative SC language for them!

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal tries to create Imperator, an imperative programming language that can write a smart contract on Cardano. The proposal has proposed a solution to a problem many developers, including myself, experience, that is transition from imperative programming paradigm to a functional one like Haskell/Plutus. If successfully implemented, the effect of the project on the Cardano ecosystem is immense. The proposal also provides a GitHub repository consisting of a prototype of the language, the GitHub repo itself is very active based on the commit history. As a developer aspiring to write smart contracts but struggling with Haskell I’m very excited and will keep up with the project. The proposal gives information on the challenge of reaching out to developers and getting their feedback on the project, however, the proposer has stated a way to overcome them.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal gives concise milestones with a simple roadmap, that is the language can compile a simple smart contract within the next 3 months. However, it can be more easily read if the milestones are written on points rather than a paragraph. The proposal gives budget information but is not broken down enough. For example, the proposal stated they will spend 50K$ as remuneration for the developer to work on the project in 9 months, which can be elaborated further as to how much the developers get paid/hour or do he/she use any paid tools? the same goes for the 20K$ that is used for marketing should be explained in more detail. The proposal does not give information on the background, relevant skills, or experience of the proposer, but the proposal provides a GitHub link that the community can decide the abilities of the proposer. It would be better if the proposal also provide a concise background and LinkedIn profiles for the proposer.
f6_assessments.q2: The metric of success are concise and very clear, the developer use the programming language measured by the number of stars/forks/downloads of the github project of the language. Those statistics indicates developers actually use it for development of smart contract on Cardano.
f6_assessments.reply: I will make sure to provide more details on the milestones and budget use. Thanks for the note!

In this part, the proposal must clearly show the roadmap, the milestones of the plan, and what the project will deliver at the time of that roadmap or at that time. Proposers should provide a realistic timeline for completing the given tasks in a logical manner. The proposal must show a reasonable plan not only in terms of what they will accomplish but also how it needs to be. The proposal should also detail the technical and technological aspects required to implement this project. The budget plan is not really detailed yet. The information provided by the proposal is still sketchy, not enough to assess whether the budget is reasonable with the proposed plan or not. Please specify more clearly the items that need to be invested and allocate capital for them. One item to consider is the amount of staff needed and key positions to carry out the project resulting in a portion of the budget needing to pay for their salaries. f6_assessments.reply: Thanks for the feedback, will be more precise on milestones and quantitative indices.

f6_assessments.q0: The goal of F8: The Great Migration is to find ways that enable EVM based dApp developers to migrate to the Haskell base Cardano Ecosystem. A major difference is the coding paradigm behind. Moreover it is well known that the paradigm of Haskell is not as wide-spread as for example Java, Python or Solidity - which makes it hard for developers to start on Plutus smart contracts. By offering a familiar feeling language, this proposal effectively opens an important path for developers to join the Cardano Ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1:
The developer has not only published his thorough experience with programming itself and a link to past successfull open-source projects - he has also provided a prototype that seems to work as advertised. The prototype is very basic but allows for the most important features and likely difficult parts to transform: loops and assignments. The coding style seems mostly clean. The project is written in Python, which hopefully further enables collaboration on the project.
The only issue is, that this strongly depends on the development of the Pluto language, which itself is marked as experimental. Hopefully, the author has a plan how to proceed in case the development of the Pluto language ceases. However the provided material and information is promising and shows sufficient knowledge of the field to conduct the project successfully in the desired timeframe.
f6_assessments.q2:
It is indeed hard to measure the success of the proposal. The progress itself can easily be measured by watching the open source repository linked for development. Assuming that the developer will continue publishing in this openly accessible repository, his productivity can be measured well.

The success measurements provided by the author are possible, but not necessarily perfect. The number of overall contracts on cardano will likely increase further, as it already did the last months. However, the metric of repository stars and followers is likely a good indication of the wellbeing and popularity of the project (looking at the IOHK repositories).

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal addresses the issue of migrating developers from Ethereum/Solidity who are experienced in Solidity (and highly likely Javascript).. giving them something that looks familiar (imperator) and getting them up and running on Cardano quickly. The proposer is correct that learning a functional language like Haskell for Plutus development is a barrier to entry to Cardano dApp development and the success of Ethereum/Solidity is that it looked allot like Javascript, and there are a lot of people who know Javascript. I believe this proposal fits the challenge very well.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer is asking to break the funds down into $50k for himself (the equivalent of US$100k/year salary) + $20K for promotion. The proposer Neils, has a decent background in programming, computer science etc, he has already displayed that he has a framework up on github and will be continuing to work on it.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer has a clear metric to check the adoption rate of this tool/language by way of seeing how many smart contracts get written in it. I would however like to see how the Marketing and Outreach can play a bigger role in getting some more rich metrics out of projects and developers who are or will be using the language.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal suggests creating a language that more similarly resembles JavaScript or Solidity to make it easier for developers to make applications on Cardano. A Github link has been provided showcasing an example initial and simple implementation with an examples folder. Due to the popularity of Solidity in the market the execution of this proposal could be a high impact proposal to help Ethereum DApp developers migrate over to Cardano. However this proposal does not aim to be EVM compatible which should be noted. This factor is important as this means for existing DApps to migrate over they would need to learn the language created by the proposer. 

It would have been beneficial for the author to mention some existing projects in this domain of simpler languages to write smart contracts such as Reach (https://reach.sh/) or Glow (https://mukn.io/). Without any mention of these or comparisons as to why this proposal will bring value beyond what they are working on, or at a minimum detail the differences and why, it becomes difficult to give a higher rating for potential impact.

Overall there is potential this proposal could help to migrate users from Ethereum if implemented effectively. However as feedback, in future proposals it is recommended the proposer adds more details on what makes this specific solution unique in comparison to the market and detail any tradeoffs to different approaches.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer does not detail out their professional history beyond mentioning they have computer scientist with the theoretical background in computer science. It would have been useful to have a LinkedIn profile or similar resource to understand the proposers professional history a little more. The GitHub provided offers some evidence that the proposer is able to execute against the proposal being suggested. There is relevant research linked and some examples given.

By going down the route of creating a new language it creates a problem of having no developers know the language when it's launched meaning a lack of online resources and examples for people to learn from. With only one developer involved in this project it is difficult to state with confidence that this proposal is feasible in terms of getting adoption. However this should not provide provide a reason to reduce the possibility that the proposer could execute and showcase something worth adopting.

The proposal would have benefited from a better breakdown of what exactly they want to support and how long each of those things will take to achieve. It would have been great to see the proposer for instance focussing on one specific area that they want to make it easier for developers to build using the language if that could provide more evidence and confidence that the proposer can indeed execute the roadmap that has been outlined.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal has added two different KPIs which are reasonable for a software project to track. These are the number of people interacting, watching or using the repository for their own usage. The project is already open source making it easy to track the progress for the community which should be noted. The roadmap could have been fleshed out more to make it easier for the community to understand when to expect and audit different parts of this proposal. The proposal could have been more specific when going through what success looks like for the project. After someone completes a "short tutorial on the imperative SC language" what do we expect a developer to be able to develop? It would have been useful to understand what coverage of the Plutus language and its capabilities will be covered so that the community can audit the execution against that to then understand the key benefits and whether this proposals execution produced a good impact

solution: Imperator is a language for SCs that looks and feels like JavaScript/Solidity, well known imperative languages popular among developers.
experience: I am trained computer scientist with the theoretical background in computer science to understand the fundamentals (I have also developed a prototype). I am experienced in developing and maintaining high quality open source projects, which I aim this language to become!
